details.description: How to become an apprentice – qualifications, pay and training, take on an apprentice - funding, employer grants and NAS

parts.title: Overview
parts.body:
Anyone in England who is 16 or over and not in full-time education can apply for an apprenticeship.

Apprenticeships are work-based programmes that combine practical training with study. They take between 1 and 4 years to complete depending on the level of apprenticeship.

An apprentice:

  • works alongside experienced staff
  • gains job-specific skills
  • earns a wage
  • studies - usually 1 day a week - towards a related qualification

Levels of apprenticeship

There are 3 levels:

  • Intermediate – equivalent to 5 GCSE passes
  • Advanced – equivalent to 2 A level passes
  • Higher Apprenticeships – lead to NVQ Level 4 or Foundation Degree

parts.title: What you get as an apprentice
parts.body:
Pay and holidays

You’ll be paid from the first day of your apprenticeship. The minimum wage for an apprentice is £2.65 per hour and applies to workers aged 18 to 20 and those aged 19 and over in the first year of their apprenticeship.

But many earn more. On average apprentices earn £170 per week and some around £210.

If you’re aged 19 or over and have completed the first year of your apprenticeship, you’ll be paid at least the National Minimum Wage rate for your age.

Apprentices get at least 20 days of holiday per year, plus bank holidays.

Qualifications

Apprenticeships can lead to:

  • National Vocational Qualifications (NVQs) at Level 2,3,4 or 5
  • Key Skills qualifications, such as in communication or ICT
  • a technical certificate, such as a BTEC or City & Guilds Progression Award
  • knowledge-based qualifications, such as a Higher National Certificate (HNC), a Higher National Diploma (HND) or a Foundation degree

Types of apprenticeships

You can find out about the different types of apprenticeships on the Apprenticeships website.

Apply

Get started and apply for an apprenticeship.

parts.title: Taking on an apprentice
parts.body:
You can use apprenticeships to train both new and existing employees. You can get funding to train apprentices.

Funding

The amount of funding you can get for apprenticeship training depends on your sector and the age of your candidate:

  • aged 16 to 18 - you get 100% of cost paid
  • aged 19 to 24 - you get 50% of cost paid
  • 25 years and older - you may only get a contribution

This is paid directly to the organisation that provides and supports the apprenticeship - in most cases the learning provider.

Apprenticeship grant for employers

You may also be eligible for a £1,500 apprenticeship grant.

These grants are available to help small-medium sized employers to recruit up to 3 apprentices for the first time, and are in addition to the training costs you get for apprentices.

Take on an apprentice

Follow the steps on the Apprenticeships website to get started.
